summary: Widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time, this mob drama, based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, focuses on the powerful Italian-American crime family of Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). When the don's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino), reluctantly joins the Mafia, he becomes involved in the inevitable cycle of violence and betrayal. Although Michael tries to maintain a normal relationship with his wife, Kay (Diane Keaton), he is drawn deeper into the family business.

 It is about the Corleone family and specifically about the father of the family Vito Corleone, the most respected mafia boss in New York, and his son Michael Corleone, who goes from being a young man oblivious to family affairs to being the boss of the mafia.

Don Vito Corleone, a mobster who refuses to immerse himself in the world of drugs, faces off against his rivals. Other clandestine families will not be too optimistic about their monopoly, the godfather's relationship will be questioned, his life will be threatened, and more conflict and revenge will follow.

The camera moves slowly and deliberately, the environment is close and natural, gravity does not give anger or anxiety, understanding is possible, and the images seamlessly shift in convincing continuity. The rhythm and stage direction serve concepts that help to understand the mafia: a culture with its own norms and values.

Violence will break out and Coppola gives us a brilliant scene, shots that create sensations that seem real. This is the strength and determination of what will happen in the rest of the movie. This classic film is about family, betrayal, power and respect. Marlon Brando gives a powerful performance as said Godfather and Al Pacino as Michael. There are many scenes with little dialogue, the emphasis being on characters facial expressions and gestures (incl. body language), to portray their feelings/emotions.

I liked the scenes shot in Italy - there are some panoramic/landscape shots and I liked that you could vividly hear the crickets/cicadas. Hearing that took me back to the holidays in Europe that I've had in the past. I also thought the christening/baptism scene, towards the end, was pretty powerful, due to the obvious dichotomy facing the viewer. I also enjoyed the scene featuring Don Corleone (snr.) and the young child in the garden - there's quite an analogy present there.

Of course this film contains many well known film quotes, such as 'I'll make them an offer they can't refuse' and multiple uses of Italian slang, aka mobster speak - 'badda boom, badda bang' etc. It was interesting to see the source material for such quotes (at least I assume they originated from this film, to some extent in any case).

The cast very much makes this film and for the cinematic atmosphere it gives, I would certainly recommend it to others.

The Godfather (1972) is a gangster flick overflowing with charm and emotion. The amazing cinematography by Gordon Willis, paired with the artful direction by Francis Ford Coppola, truly complemented the majestic performances by the likes of Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Diane Keaton, James Caan, Robert Duvall, just to name a few. The film dwells into the fragility of the American Dream, and ultimately, life. Through the artful depiction of the mafia life, we came to sympathize with the characters in the films; even though we knew deep in our hearts that they are flawed in so many ways. On a different note, the theme song of the film, Love Theme from The Godfather by Nino Rota, is probably one of the most recognizable musical pieces out there; it is essentially up there with the likes of Vivaldi's Le quattro stagioni, Beethoven's Quasi una fantasia, and Mozart's Piano Sonata No. 11, among others.

Not much can be said about Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather that hasn't already be said.  An American classic, it's set in 1940s New York and documents the Corleone family and their struggle for power within the crime world.  Marlon Brando is great in the title role, as are James Caan and Al Pacino as two of his sons.  The score is iconic, the period details are spot on, and the whole film is beautifully executed.  At the risk of committing cinematic heresy, if there is one possible complaint it could be the length of the movie, which clocks in at just under three hours.  Some scenes simply feel too long – for example, the opening wedding scene runs almost thirty minutes and while it is important to establish the hierarchy within the family and introduce characters, there are a lot of details that just don't matter.  Despite that, it is a classic that needs to be seen.

Directed by the great Francis Ford Coppola, the film stars Al Pacino and Marlon Brando. This masterpiece tell the story of a family of italian mafioso, who lives in the New York state in US. The story will quickly turn into a tragedy after some tragic evenement who will emotionally hustle the characters except Vito Corleone, THE Godfather, who always impresses us with his devastating calm, his wit and his charisma. The plot can seem to be just dark and violent without any reflexion behind it, but it's false. The plot is excellent and very intellectually stimuling.
There isn't a lot of special effect, because it's a realistic film, maybe the blood can seem a little exagerated but it isn't that important. The photography can be criticize but for a 1974's film, it's really good and make the film even better because it add a very dark and vintage atmosphere (without it, The Godfather wouldn't be The Godfather). Moreover, the acting is excellent too. The actors, in addition to be very known and succesfull, have been spectacular and very compelling. And, because the acting isn't all, the script of the film, based on Mario Puzo's novel, is also interesting and very tought-provoking.
In conclusion, ... if you haven't seen it yet, see it. This film is an absolute masterpiece. The casting is incredible, the acting is outstanding, the atmosphere is captivating and the plot is excellent .

The Godfather directed by master filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola is simply one of the best movies of all time. Simply a masterpiece and cinema at its best. A work of art that puts all filmmaking aspects to work to perfection: the script, direction, cinematography, and the acting performances are top to notch. Based on the novel by Mario Puzo The Godfather is the story of how the mafia don of the Corleone family begins to grow old and weak and how he passes his legacy to his son. This story takes almost three hours to tell and is epic. The two leads are as great as it gets. The titan Marlon Brandon at the pinnacle of his career plays the Godfather  an old man who faces new enemies as the mafia gets into the narcotics business. His son Michael is played by Al Pacino in one of the best performances of his career if not the best. He is handsome and does not want to be a criminal but progressively becomes a calculated killer who does not blink in this epic drama filled with violence and the complexity of morality. The editing is phenomenal and this film is simply a treasure. A true piece of cinema and perhaps the best film directed by Coppola.

There is very little that I can add to the reviews on here, that have explained what is so wonderful about The Godfather so well. I have seen many amazing movies, as well as some clunkers, but The Godfather was beyond amazing. There are so many images, details and scenes that I seriously cannot get out of my head since watching it for the first time just nine hours ago. The Godfather is so incredibly well-made and acted that it stands out among the rest of those other amazing films I've seen, so much so I couldn't think of a single flaw, and I am struggling to think of a good enough reason to why I didn't see this film before now.

True, The Godfather is a little slow-moving and the plot takes a while to unfold, but neither of these are flaws as such. The slow pacing added to the elegiac quality The Godfather has, and as for the plot what is special about this plot is that it is very unpredictable because you have next to no idea where it is next going to take you. Being 18, I was worried whether I was old enough to appreciate this film or even understand it, but luckily I understood it perfectly, and I can well and truly appreciate it for the masterpiece it is considered to be.

The Godfather for one thing looks stunning. I strongly disagree with the previous reviewer who said the cinematography was horrid, for me the cinematography was one of the best assets of the film. In some scenes you have cinematography and lighting that is quite dark and mysterious, and then in scenes such as the wedding it is evergreen, autumnal and very picturesque. It is not just the cinematography that makes The Godfather look stunning, the costumes are beautifully tailored, the houses are gorgeous and majestic to look at and even the cars were immaculate.

Then there is the score by Nina Rota. One word, outstanding! I have heard many wonderful scores in my lifetime, but after hearing this score few stick in the memory as much as the score for The Godfather. This score is both beautiful as seen with the main theme, and haunting in the way it sticks in your head after watching the film itself. Other outstanding assets are the masterly direction from Francis Ford Coppola, and the brilliantly written screenplay that is intelligent, thought-provoking and darkly humorous. As for the violence, some of it is shocking and intense especially in the climax which was enough to almost make your heart either beat twice as fast or stop, and I almost covered my eyes when the producer found the horse's head in his bed, but underneath that this family is somewhat loyal and honourable come to think of it.

The acting is absolutely fantastic, bringing to life characters that are rich and complex, perhaps unlikeable at first but as you get to know them you warm to them. And I have to say, The Godfather is one of those rarities where no actor gives a weak performance. In particular, Marlon Brando is brilliant as Don Vito, very heavily disguised yet stately. Every word of dialogue, every subtle hand gesture and every facial expression was brilliantly judged. Al Pacino's casting was admittedly risky, but he still did a truly wonderful job carrying the film, while James Caan is dignified and loyal, Diane Keaton beautiful and alluring and Robert Duvall nicely understated.

In conclusion, absolutely amazing, and I can see completely why it is considered one of the 10 greatest movies ever made, it is that good. In fact my 15-year old brother loved it so much, he wants to see it again. 10/10, though this film is too good for that rating. Bethany Cox
